title: 106_s2463
content: The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with most individuals facing capital charges unable to afford their own attorney and no state meeting ABA standards for indigent prisoners' legal representation. Since 1976, African-Americans have accounted for a disproportionate percentage of those executed and on death row in the American and Federal systems. In death penalty cases, the majority of victims are white, despite only half of murder victims being white. The Subcommittee on Civil and Constitutional Rights in 1994 found that 89% of defendants chosen for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. In 1990, the General Accounting Office reported racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and the death penalty. Prisoner appeals have been limited, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and sentences in Federal courts, even with compelling evidence of innocence. Legislation in 1996 limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners. The Federal Government and States are prohibited from carrying out the death penalty until Congress reviews the final findings of the National Commission on the Death Penalty and enacts legislation based on the Commission's recommendations. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President in consultation with relevant officials. Members include Federal or State prosecutors and experienced attorneys. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, capital defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals from various backgrounds such as government officials, academia, nonprofit organizations, industry, and other interested parties. The President aims to ensure a balanced representation of viewpoints on the use of the death penalty among the Commission members. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President from various backgrounds. The appointments of the initial members should be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all initial members being appointed. Meetings are called by the Chairperson, and a majority of members constitute a quorum. The President appoints 1 member to serve as Chair of the Commission. A majority of members form a quorum for business, and fewer can hold hearings. The Commission adopts rules for its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission adopts rules for its proceedings. The Commission conducts a study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles and fairness. This includes examining racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging and sentencing decisions. The Commission examines disparities in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions based on factors like geographic location and income status of defendants. It also evaluates the adequacy of representation for capital defendants, following ABA guidelines and policies to ensure competency of counsel in death penalty cases. The Commission evaluates disparities in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions, as well as the adequacy of representation for capital defendants. Key issues include wrongful convictions, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, and the independent judgment of courts in constitutional claims. The Commission evaluates disparities in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions, as well as the adequacy of representation for capital defendants. Key issues include wrongful convictions, federal government seeking death penalty in states without it, and the independent judgment of courts in constitutional claims. Whether mentally retarded persons and persons under 18 at the time of their offenses should be sentenced to death, procedures for access to forensic evidence and DNA testing for new evidence of innocence, and ensuring fair and impartial administration of death penalty cases in accordance with the Constitution. The Commission shall establish guidelines and procedures for the administration of the death penalty to ensure fair and impartial cases, minimize the risk of executing innocent persons, and comply with due process. The Commission will submit a preliminary report within 1 year and a final report within 2 years after the enactment of the Act to the President, Attorney General, and Congress. The reports will contain findings and conclusions on ensuring the fair and non-discriminatory administration of the death penalty. The Commission will submit reports to the President, Attorney General, and Congress with detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 203. The Commission may obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as outlined in Section 203. The Commission may conduct hearings, receive testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather information for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this title. The Commission may issue subpoenas for gathering information and have the authority to enforce them through court orders if necessary. The court can issue orders for a person to testify or produce evidence, failure to comply may result in contempt charges. Additionally, a court can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to produce a person in custody before the Commission. Witnesses appearing before the Commission may receive allowances and fees as per section 1821 of title 28, United States Code, paid from Commission funds. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation. They are allowed travel expenses and the Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Commission can appoint and terminate an executive director and additional personnel necessary for its duties. The Chairperson can set their compensation without following certain federal employment regulations. The Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates capped at level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates capped at level V of the Executive Schedule. Individuals not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V can be appointed. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. It can spend up to $850,000 for its operations, funded by the Department of Justice.
